leg:heading.title: PLEADINGS CONCERNING DEFAMATION [rr 14.30–14.40]

p.text: [Div 6 insrt Amendment 5 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[3], effective 1 January 2006]

The Defamation Act 2005 applies to the publication of defamatory matter after the commencement of that Act. The Act commenced on 1 January 2006. However, the Defamation Act 1974 (as in force before its repeal by the Defamation Act 2005) continues to apply to the following causes of action by virtue of clause 2 (Application of this Act) of Schedule 4 (Savings, transitional and other provisions) to the Defamation Act 2005:
a cause of action for defamation that accrued before 1 January 2006,
a cause of action for defamation that accrued after the commencement of the Defamation Act 2005, but only if:
the action is raised in proceedings that include other causes of action that accrued before 1 January 2006, and
the action accrued no later than 12 months after the earliest pre-1 January 2006 action accrued, and
each action in the proceedings arose out of the publication of the same, or substantially the same, matter on different occasions.

Clause 2 of Schedule 4 to the Defamation Act 2005 also ensures that any other law (both legislative and common law) that would have applied to such causes of action but for the enactment of the new Act will continue to apply to such causes of action.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.30] r 14.30 Allegations in statements of claim generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 11; DCR Part 49, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Allegations in statements of claim generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 11; DCR Part 49, rule 10)

p.text: A statement of claim seeking relief in relation to the publication of defamatory matter must not include any allegation that the matter or its publication was false, malicious or unlawful.
Any such statement of claim must:
subject to subrule (3), specify each imputation on which the plaintiff relies, and
allege that the imputation was defamatory of the plaintiff.

A plaintiff in proceedings for defamation must not rely on two or more imputations alleged to be made by the defendant by means of the same publication of the same matter unless the imputations differ in substance.
Legislation cited in [14.30.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 10, s 23.

Defamation proceedings cannot be maintained in relation to publications by or about deceased persons: Defamation Act 2005 s 10 . Leave is required to pursue proceedings if the publication has already been the subject of any defamation proceedings against the same defendant: Defamation Act 2005 s 23 .Trading corporations, those employing more than 10 persons (if unrelated to other corporations) and public corporations cannot maintain an action for defamation: see Defamation Act 2005 s 9 and Defamation Act 1974 s 8A. A statutory authority cannot maintain an action for defamation in respect of publications that reflect adversely on the performance of its functions: Ballina Shire Council v Ringland (1994) 33 NSWLR 680; 83 LGERA 115; BC9405013Â (local government authority whose members were popularly elected); Derbyshire County Council v Times Newspapers Ltd [1993] AC 534; [1993] 1 All ER 1011; [1993] 2 WLR 449Â ; New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council v Jones (1998) 43 NSWLR 300; 97 LGERA 322; BC9800711Â (authority incorporated under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983). Such an authority may, however, be able to maintain proceedings for malicious falsehood: New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council v Jones , above. Causes of action in defamation are limited to living persons — proceedings cannot be brought in relation to defamatory matter published by or about deceased persons: Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 10 .

level.toc-caption: [14.30.10] Preliminary allegations in the statement of claim

heading.title: Preliminary allegations in the statement of claim

p.text: A statement of claim in defamation proceedings may include material allegations about the identity of the parties, their occupations and their relationship to each other. However preliminary allegations of this kind should be as short and concise as materiality and readability permit. Unnecessary and irrelevant descriptive material may be embarrassing (if its materiality is not demonstrable) and is liable to be struck out: Singleton v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 20 February 1980, unreported) at p 14.

Assessment of the defamatory character of the impugned publication depends on the hypothesis of shared moral and social standards and a uniform understanding of the meaning of the content of the impugned publication: Reader’s Digest Services Pty Ltd v Lamb (1982) 150 CLR 500 at 506; 38 ALR 417; 56 ALJR 214; BC8200045Â per Brennan J. In determining the meaning of a particular publication the court will consider what it is capable of conveying to the “ordinary reasonable reader”: Favell v Queensland Newspapers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 186; 79 ALJR 1716; [2005] HCA 52; BC200507180Â per Gleeson CJ, McHugh, Gummow and Heydon JJ. Various explanatory descriptions have been applied in determining the hypothesised qualities of such a reader. These include the propositions that they are fair and of average intelligence; Slayter v The Daily Telegraph Newspaper Co Ltd (1908) 6 CLR 1 at 7Â ; and have a capacity for “right-thinking” Sim v Stretch [1936] 2 All ER 1237 at 1240Â . The hypothesised “ordinary reader” does not live in an ivory tower: Lewis v Daily Telegraph Ltd [1964] AC 2384 atÂ 25; [1963] 2 All ER 151; [1963] 2 WLR 1063Â ; but does not have a perverse, morbid or suspicious of mind: Keogh v Incorporated Dental Hospital of Ireland [1910] 2 IR 577 at 586Â . These propositions should not be allowed to operate as more than explanations, and not restrictive refinements, of the essentially practical and impressionistic assessment required to be made: Favell v Queensland Newspapers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 186; 79 ALJR 1716; [2005] HCA 52 at [20]ff; BC200507180Â per Kirby J. Generally speaking a defamatory statement must be disparaging. Statements may also be defamatory, even if they do not convey moral fault or blame, if they portray the plaintiff in a ridiculous light or otherwise tend to have other persons “shun or avoid” the plaintiff: Boyd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 449 at 452–453Â per Hunt J. Statements are defamatory if they “tend to lower the plaintiff in the estimation of right-thinking members of society generally”: see Sim v Stretch [1936] 2 All ER 1237 at 1240; (1936) 52 TLR 669Â per Lord Atkin; or “are of a kind likely to lead ordinary decent folk to think the less of the person about whom the statement was made”: Consolidated Trust Co Ltd v Browne (1948) 49 SR (NSW) 86 at 88; 66 WN (NSW) 7Â per Jordan CJ.
Legislation cited in [14.30.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 14.30(2)(a), r 14.30(3).
(NSW) Defamation Act 1974 s 9(2).
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 8.

The alleged defamatory content of a publication is the “imputation” it conveys: Drummoyne Municipal Council v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1990) 21 NSWLR 135 at 136; BC9001671Â . An imputation is the particular act or condition attributed by the publication (according to the understanding of the ordinary reasonable reader) to the person allegedly defamed: Hall-Gibbs Mercantile Agency Ltd v Dun (1910) 12 CLR 84 at 91; [1910] HCA 66Â ; Sungravure Pty Ltd v Middle East Airlines Airliban SAL (1975) 134 CLR 1 at 10; (1975) 5 ALR 147; BC7500011Â ; Petritsis v Hellenic Herald Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 174 at 183Â ; Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684Â at [119]–[120], [125], [129].

The requirement in UCPR rÂ 14.30(2)(a) makes it fundamentally important that the pleadings specify the particular imputation on which the plaintiff relies: Drummoyne Municipal Council v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1990) 21 NSWLR 135; BC9001671 at 136 , 137Â cited with approval in Nationwide News Pty Ltd v Murphy (1999) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-506; [1999] NSWCA 118; BC9902076Â ; see Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden (1998) 43 NSWLR 158; BC9800086 at 162Â and the authorities cited therein. (This is particularly the case in relation to proceedings under s 9(2) of the Defamation Act 1974, where each defamatory imputation conveyed by the same publication creates a separate cause of action; Petritsis v Hellenic Herald Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 174 at 190Â and Monte v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 663 at 676 and 678Â ; contrast s 8 of the Defamation Act 2005, which provides a single cause of action for the same publication.) A plaintiff can rely on multiple imputations arising from the same publication if the imputations “differ in substance”: see r 14.30(3) . The plaintiff’s claim will then be confined to the pleaded imputation, and any variation that can properly be advanced by amendment without material prejudice or disadvantage to the defendant: Chakravarti v Advertiser NewspapersÂ Ltd (1998) 193Â CLR 519; 154Â ALR 294; [1998] HCA 37; BC9801849 at [24]–[25], [60] and [139]Â .
Legislation cited in [14.30.22] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 14.30(2)(a).

The specification required by UCPR rÂ 14.30(2)(a) obliges the plaintiff to plead the particular defamatory meaning the impugned publication would allegedly convey to an ordinary reasonable reader: Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [125]Â and [129]; Feros v West Sydney Radio Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 22 June 1982, unreported, BC8200027) (sufficient to plead an imputation that the defendant had conducted a business in a “disgraceful manner with irresponsible disregard” for the rights of others): Drummoyne Municipal Council v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1990) 21 NSWLR 135 at 140 A-E; BC9001671Â (insufficiently precise to plead an imputation that the defendant was “corrupt”); Drummoyne Municipal Council v Australian Broadcasting Corp , above; Marsden v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Levine J, No 20223/95, 4 May 1998, unreported, BC9801561). The question whether an imputation has been sufficiently “specified” is ordinarily one to be resolved by considerations of practical justice (rather than philology) in the circumstances of a particular case: John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Foord (1988) 12 NSWLR 706Â (sufficiently precise to plead an imputation that the defendant was a “criminal associate of drug dealers” and that he was a “corrupt judge”). The real issue is whether there is likely to be confusion, either at the pleading stage or at the trial, in relation to the meaning for which the plaintiff contends: Whelan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 148 at 155Â , cited in Darbyshir v Daily Examiner Pty Ltd BC9701617). Nevertheless, the obligation to specify imputations is not necessarily discharged merely by repeating the actual words of the publication. A pleading in that form will not comply with the present rule if it is likely to result in confusion about the precise defamatory meaning for which the plaintiff contends: Harvey v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWCA 255; BC200505684 at [119]–[120], [122]–[129]Â ; Whelan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd , above (imputation of corrupt conduct insufficiently precise); Monte v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 663 at 676 and 678Â (“it is the meaning alleged to have been conveyed by the words, rather than the words themselves, which it is important to have precisely defined”); Jones v Skelton [1963] SR (NSW) 644 at 650Â ; [1964] NSWR 485. For much the same reason, it is unlikely that a pleader's obligation to produce precise imputations be fulfilled where the imputation is cast in a passive voice: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 36 at 42Â (insufficiently precise to allege an imputation that a person has been charged with a criminal offence).

Differing imputations should not be “rolled up” into the one sentence but should be separately pleaded: Monte v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2Â NSWLR 663 at 677. The purpose of r 14.30(2) and (3) is not to confine a plaintiff, or a defendant, to the precise terms of the pleaded imputations. Rather the basic purpose is to preclude the duplicated pleading of substantially similar imputations arising from the same publication: Morosi v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 749 at 771Â (Court of Appeal); Callaghan v Emanuel (NSWSC, Hunt J, 24 July 1981, unreported) (imputations should, so far as is possible, be simple and straightforward). Where one imputation alleges conduct on a particular instance and another alleges such conduct generally the requirement of r 14.30(3) that “the imputations differ in substance” is usually satisfied: Singleton v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 20 February 1980, unreported); Maisel v Financial Times Ltd (1915) 84 LJKB 2145; 112 LT 953Â . Similarly a statement that the defendant stole from a client may properly justify separate imputations of (i) criminal dishonesty and (ii) breach of professional duty: Singleton v Ffrench (1986) 5 NSWLR 425 at 428–9Â . Where the pleaded causes of action rely on the same pleaded imputations but in relation to separate publications, the trial judge should consider exercising the power conferred by s 22(4) of the Defamation Act 2005 (or s 9(5) of the Defamation Act 1974) to require the jury to return separate verdicts: TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Antoniadis (1998) 44 NSWLR 682; BC9805043Â .

Sometimes the allegedly defamatory publication consists of images, pictures or other non-verbal depictions. The pictures or images themselves cannot be part of a pleading: Ron Hodgson (Trading) Pty Ltd v Belvedere Motors (Hurstville) Pty Ltd [1971] 1 NSWLR 472 at 481–2Â . Where the claim relates to a publication of this type the statement of claim must assert what the plaintiff claims the published matter represents: Redmond v Advertiser-News Weekend Publishing Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, HuntÂ J, 20 February 1980, unreported) at 2; AB Parry & Sons Pty Ltd v KG Murray Publishing Co Pty Ltd BC8000045Â at 10; Stewart v Shoalhaven & Nowra News Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 26 September 1980, unreported) at p 1. In pleading the effect of an image or picture it is sufficient to plead conclusions of fact rather than describe the specific images from which those conclusions may be drawn: Gordon v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 410 at 415–16Â .

If the impugned publication was made in a non-English language, the pleaded imputations must apply to the English translation of the publication. It is not sufficient that the imputations only arise from the non-English version of the publication: Stiefanovich v Balac [1978] ACLD 164.

level.toc-caption: [14.30.40] Context of imputations must be included

heading.title: Context of imputations must be included

p.text: A plaintiff may include in the statement of claim, and indeed ought confine it to, matters that provide the context necessary to explain the true meaning and significance of the imputations, and their reference to the plaintiff. But the defamatory effect of the matter complained of must be determined by taking into account the relevant context of the whole of the publication: Australian Newspaper Co Ltd v Bennett [1894] AC 284 at 288; (1894) 11 WN (NSW) 1Â ; Grand Theatre & Opera House (Glasgow) Ltd v G Outram & Co [1909] SC 1018 at 1019; Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Bridges (HCA, 28 July 1971, unreported); Mirror Newspapers Ltd v World Hosts Pty Ltd (1979) 141 CLR 632; 23 ALR 167; BC7900010Â ; Gordon v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 410 at 413Â : Favell v Queensland Newspapers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 186; 79 ALJR 1716; [2005] HCA 52 at [17]; BC200507180Â (newspaper article of fire linked with controversial redevelopment proposal — imputations of arson and suspicion of arson). Consequently, if the nature and significance of imputations contended for are altered or qualified by other passages in the publication, the plaintiff must also include those other passages in the statement of claim: Beran v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 107; BC200401716Â ; Gordon v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd , above, at 413; Ron Hodgson (Trading) Pty Ltd v Belvedere Motors (Hurstville) Pty Ltd [1971] 1 NSWLR 472 at 477Â ; Tsvangirai v Special Broadcasting Service [2002] NSWSC 532; BC200203180Â ; Dougherty v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 146 at 149Â , 151. This principle applies equally to oral and written defamation: Gordon v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd , above, at 414. It may also apply to separate, but related, publications: Burrows v Knightley & Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1987) 10Â NSWLR 651 at 655. A plaintiff may be ordered to replead a statement of claim if additional passages relied upon by a defendant may (not must) be understood by the ordinary, reasonable reader as materially altering or qualifying the complexion of the imputations contended for by a plaintiff: Gordon v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd , above, at 415.

A pleaded imputation may be struck out if the plaintiff's claim that it is conveyed by the matter complained of, or is defamatory of them, is so obviously untenable that it is groundless and cannot possibly succeed: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 129; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Bik v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 679; Monte v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 663 at 675Â ; Einfeld v Bread Manufacturers of New South Wales (NSWSC, Hunt J, 10 February 1981, unreported). A defendant is not debarred from complaining as to the form of a plaintiff's imputation by having pleaded to the statement of claim: Whatman v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (NSWSC, HuntÂ J, 20 February 1980, unreported, BC8000047). In assessing the defamatory capacity of the pleaded imputation regard may be had to the particulars supplied by the plaintiff (and to any reasonable arguable amendment or elaboration of them) in order to demonstrate the futility of the claim: Searle v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1974] 1 NSWLR 180 at 186–7Â ; Pearson v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd [1971] 1 NSWLR 189 at 191Â ; Cowan v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 10 October 1980, unreported). An application to strike out an imputation is not restricted to cases where the plaintiff's claim is untenable or groundless. It extends to those cases where the terms of the imputation is not sufficiently particularised: see Whelan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 12Â NSWLR 148; or where the terms of the imputation could be said to be ambiguous: see Singleton v Ffrench (1986) 5 NSWLR 425Â ; But applications made on these grounds ought not be concluded adversely to a plaintiff if the defects are capable of legitimate amendment: Krahe v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 536 at 543Â .

A statement of claim may be amended to include any imputation that fairly arises from the impugned publication: If the amended imputation proposed is not so obviously untenable as to warrant its being summarily struck out, and the amendment application has been made in a timely manner, leave to amend would normally be granted: Cadam v Beaverbrook Newspapers Ltd [1959] 1 QB 413 at 425Â ; Abela v Giew (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 344Â and Dawson Bloodstock Agency Pty Ltd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 733 at 739Â . The general principles upon which amendments will be granted are found in the annotations to s 64 of the CPA.
Legislation cited in [14.30.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 ssÂ 21, 22.

Either party may elect for a jury trial of issues other than damages: ssÂ 21, 22 Defamation Act 2005 and see [29.2.15] . Irrespective of the mode of trial, the defamatory capacity of the publication (ie its reference to the plaintiff, whether it conveys the imputation alleged and whether that imputation is defamatory) may be the subject of separate determination before the other issues in the proceedings: Love v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 112 at 122Â and see UCPR r 28.2. Where such a separate hearing is ordered it requires determination of two distinct questions of law: (i) whether the matter complained of is capable of conveying the imputations specified by the plaintiff; and (ii) whether those imputations are capable of defaming the plaintiff: Monte v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 663 at 668Â ; Capital & Counties Bank Ltd v George Henty & Sons (1882) 7 App Cas 741 at 772Â . In determining whether or not an imputation is capable of being conveyed by the impugned publication, the court is required to determine the meaning capable of being conveyed to an ordinary reasonable person to whom the material was published. For that purpose, the reasonable person may be assumed to be a person of average intelligence who is neither perverse nor avid for scandal but who is not a lawyer and is able to “read between the lines” — depending, in particular, on the manner of the particular publication: Farquhar v Bottom [1980] 2 NSWLR 380Â ; Boyd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 449Â ; Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden. (1998) 43 NSWLR 158Â . The fact that the plaintiff pleads reliance on true innuendoes (ie a secondary or extended meaning of the publication: see [15.19.25] ) will not necessarily dictate refusal of an application for separate determination: Cowan v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 10 October 1980, unreported).

The principles that apply to dismissal of proceedings for lack of despatch are dealt with in [12.7.5]. There is a particular discussion of their application to defamation proceedings in see Burke v TCN Channel Nine Ltd (NSWSC, Levine J, No 10688/89, 16 December 1994, unreported, BC9403394); Vilo v John Fairfax and Sons Ltd (NSWSC, Sperling J, 17 November 1995, unreported) and Bass v TCN Channel Nine Ltd (NSWSC, Levine J, 25 July 1997, unreported, BC9703238).

level.toc-caption: [14.30.65] Further proceedings in relation to same defamatory matter

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.30.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 23.

heading.title: Further proceedings in relation to same defamatory matter

p.text: A plaintiff requires leave to bring further proceedings on the same defamatory matter even if the earlier proceedings were brought outside New South Wales: Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 23 .

level.toc-caption: [14.30.70] Exemplary and punitive damages not available

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.30.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 37.

heading.title: Exemplary and punitive damages not available

p.text: Pursuant to Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 37 exemplary and punitive damages cannot be awarded for defamation. See further note at [15.19.35]

level.toc-caption: [14.30.75] Distinction between libel and slander abolished

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.30.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 7.

heading.title: Distinction between libel and slander abolished

p.text: The distinction between libel (written publication) and slander, (verbal and therefore temporary) publication has been abolished: Defamation Act 2005 sÂ 7 . All publications of defamatory matter are actionable without proof of material loss (special damage).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.31] r 14.31 Defamation defences generally (cf SCR Part 67, rules 13 and 19(1); DCR Part 49, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Defamation defences generally (cf SCR Part 67, rules 13 and 19(1); DCR Part 49, rule 12)

p.text: Subject to rules 14.32–14.40 , a defendant in proceedings for defamation must plead any defamation defence specifically.
If the plaintiff in defamation proceedings complains of two or more imputations, the pleading of any of the following defences must specify to what imputation or imputations the defence is pleaded:
a defence under section 15(2) or 16(2) of the Defamation Act 1974,
a defence under section 25 or 26 of the Defamation Act 2005,
the defence of justification at common law.
If a plaintiff intends to meet any defamation defence:
by alleging that the defendant was actuated by express malice in the publication of the matter complained of, or
by relying on any matter which, under the Defamation Act 1974 or the Defamation Act 2005, defeats the defence,
then the plaintiff must plead that allegation or matter of defeasance by way of reply.
Legislation cited in [14.31.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 24.

The rule requires all defences to be specifically pleaded, except to the extent that the rules otherwise permit an abbreviated form of pleading that refers to a recognised ground of defence. In addition to the defences provided for in the Rules, any other defence or exclusion of liability is available to a defendant including under the general law: Defamation Act 2005 s 24 . It is not an abuse of the court's process in a defence to put the plaintiff to proof of the issues of publication, identification and defamation: Casey v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1981] 1 NSWLR 305 at 307–8Â ; Pinson v Lloyds and National Provincial Foreign Bank Ltd [1941] 2 KB 72 at 81–2; [1941] 2 All ER 636Â . Inconsistent defences are also permitted: Casey , above, at 308–9.
Legislation cited in [14.31.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 11.

Where the law of a non-Australian law area governs the cause of action defences available by virtue of the lex loci delicti may be pleaded in an action for defamation in addition to the defences available by virtue of the lex fori: Koop v Bebb (1951) 84Â CLR 629; [1952] ALR 37Â ; Anderson v Eric Anderson Radio & TV Pty Ltd (1965) 114 CLR 20; [1966] ALR 423; BC6500520Â ; Cawley v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 225Â . But if the governing law is that of another Australian state or territory, it is likely that only defences available under that governing law will be able to be pleaded: John Pfeiffer Pty Ltd v Rogerson (2000) 203 CLR 503; 172 ALR 625; [2000] HCA 36; BC200003351Â . Where the proceedings are subject to the Defamation Act 2005, and the publication occurs in more than one “Australian jurisdictional area” the court is required to apply the substantive law of the place that has the “closest connection” with the harm alleged by the plaintiff: see s 11 of the Defamation Act 2005.

level.toc-caption: [14.31.15] Malice required to be pleaded in reply

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.31.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 24(2).

heading.title: Malice required to be pleaded in reply

p.text: Whether a publication was actuated by malice is to be determined under the general law: Defamation Act 2005 s 24(2) . Under the general law a publication is actuated by malice if it is published with the dominant motive of either personal spite or with a desire to injure. It connotes publication for an extraneous purpose or motive: Robert v Bass (2002) 212 CLR 1 at 30–33; 194 ALR 161; [2002] HCA 57; BC200207519Â . Malice, in this sense, may exist despite a defendant’s honest belief in the truth of the publication, or a duty to publish: Horrocks v Lowe [1975] AC 135 at 149; [1974] 1 All ER 662Â . (On the other hand, an erroneous, as distinct from a recklessly idiosyncratic, belief in the truth of the publication is not necessarily evidence of malice: Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [46]Â .) A reply relying on a defence of malice must expressly allege malice and not merely a lack of good faith: Humphreys v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 18 April 1980, unreported, BC8000031) at [7]–[8]. Particulars of allegations of malice in reply should be of the facts and matters relied upon and not the ultimate fact to be inferred from those facts and matters: NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan [1982] 1 NSWLR 585 at 603Â ; King v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 1Â NSWLR 31 at 32; Aldridge v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1984] 2 NSWLR 544 at 549Â ; Waterhouse v Broadcasting Station 2GB Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 58 at 67Â . A finding of malice with respect to one publication in a connected series can be relevant to the question whether malice has infected other related publications, so as to deprive them of the defence of qualified privilege: Mowlds v Fergusson (1939) 40 SR (NSW) 311 at 327–30Â ; Robert v Bass (2002) 212 CLR 1; 194 ALR 161 at 213; [2002] HCA 57; BC200207519Â . As to the necessity for pleading a limited allegation of malice in reply to common law and statutory fair comment see Cawley v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 225 at 238–9Â .

level.toc-caption: [14.31.20] Offer of Amends in defamation proceedings as a complete defence to the action

heading.title: Offer of Amends in defamation proceedings as a complete defence to the action

p.text: See the note at [29.16.5] on the effect of failure by a plaintiff to accept an offer of amends.

The objective truth or falsity of the matter complained of is irrelevant to its characterisation as defamatory: Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [88]Â ; GÂ Spencer Bower, Law of Actionable Defamation, 2nd ed, Butterworths & Co, London, 1923, at 236–237. See also Clines v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd [1965] NSWR 604; (1965) 66 SR (NSW) 321 at 327Â ; Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Uren [1969] 1 AC 590; (1969) 117 CLR 185 at 205; BC6600050Â ; Ross McConnell Kitchen & Co Pty Ltd v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1980] 2Â NSWLR 845 at 847. (Truth or falisty may be relevant to a claim for aggravated damages: Rigby v Associated Newspapers Ltd (No 2) [1969] 1 NSWR 729 at 738Â ; see also King v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 31 at 33Â ; Singleton v Ffrench (1986) 5 NSWLR 425 at 442–4Â .) And an honest belief in the truth of the publication does not provide an absolute defence. However, even where there is no “substantial truth” defence, a plaintiff is always entitled to attempt to prove the falsity of the published imputation: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Uren, above; Rigby v Associated Newspapers Ltd (No 2), above,at 743Â ; Ainsworth v Burden, above. If the plaintiff does assert the falsity of what was published, the defendant is entitled to meet that claim by demonstrating that what was published is true: Howden v Truth & Sportsman Ltd (1937) 58 CLR 416 at 432–3Â ; Rigby v Associated Newspapers Ltd (No 2), above,at 739Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.32] r 14.32 Defence of justification generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 14; DCR Part 49, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Defence of justification generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 14; DCR Part 49, rule 13)
Defence under Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Subject to rule 14.31(2) , a defence under section 15(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges:
that the imputation in question was a matter of substantial truth, and
either:
that the imputation in question related to a matter of public interest, or
that the imputation in question was published under qualified privilege.
The defence of justification under section 15(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 applies to the exclusion of the common law defence of justification. See section 15(1) of the Defamation Act 1974.

leg:heading.title: Defences under Defamation Act 2005 and at common law

p.text: Subject to rule 14.31(2) , a defence of justification under section 25 of the Defamation Act 2005 or at common law is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the imputation in question was substantially true.

The defence of justification under section 25 of the Defamation Act 2005 is in addition to, and does not vitiate, limit or abrogate, the common law defence of justification. See section 24(1) of the Defamation Act 2005
Legislation cited in [14.32.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 25.
(NSW) Defamation Act 1974 sÂ 15(2).

In pleading a defence under s 25 of the Defamation Act 2005 or sÂ 15(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 and in giving particulars of that defence, a defendant may have to address the possible distinction between, on the one hand, the available defamatory inferences (imputations) of the words used and, on the other, the capacity of the facts stated in the publication (if proved) to establish the truth of those imputations: Lewis v Daily Telegraph Ltd [1964] AC 234Â ; Lang v Australian Consolidated Press [1970] 2 NSWR 408Â ; Dawson Bloodstock Agency Pty Ltd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 733 at 738Â and Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 36 at 41Â . Whelan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 148 at 160Â . As to whether a defendant who pleads justification must plead the imputation which they intend to justify and whether they will be confined at trial to justification of the pleaded imputation see Lucas–Box v News Group Newspapers Ltd [1986] 1 WLR 147Â . Compare Morrell v International Thomson Publishing Ltd [1983] 3 All ER 733 at 737–8 and 740.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.33] r 14.33 Defence of contextual truth (cf SCR Part 67, rule 15; DCR Part 49, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Defence of contextual truth (cf SCR Part 67, rule 15; DCR Part 49, rule 14)
Defence under Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Subject to rule 14.31(2) , a defence under section 16 of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if it:
alleges either:
that the imputation in question related to a matter of public interest, or
that the imputation in question was published under qualified privilege, and
specifies one or more imputations on which the defendant relies as being contextual to the imputation in question, and
as to the contextual imputations on which the defendant relies:
alleges either that they related to a matter of public interest or that they were published under qualified privilege, and
alleges that they were matters of substantial truth, and

alleges that, by reason that the contextual imputations on which the defendant relies are matters of substantial truth, the imputation in question did not further injure the reputation of the plaintiff.

leg:heading.title: Defence under Defamation Act 2005

p.text: Subject to rule 14.31(2) , a defence under section 26 of the Defamation Act 2005 is sufficiently pleaded if it:
specifies one or more imputations on which the defendant relies as being contextual to the imputation in question, and
alleges each contextual imputation on which the defendant relies was substantially true, and
alleges that the imputation in question did not further harm the reputation of the plaintiff because of the contextual imputations on which the defendant relies.
Legislation cited in [14.33.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 26.
(NSW) Defamation Act 1974 sÂ 16.

A defence of contextual truth under s 26 of the Defamation Act 2005 (or sÂ 16 of the Defamation Act 1974) implicitly accepts the defamatory nature of the imputations relied on by the plaintiff. The essence of the defence is that, because of the nature and content of additional, and true, imputations contextually conveyed by the same publication, the allegedly defamatory imputation(s) relied on by the plaintiff could not have caused any further injury to the plaintiff’s reputation: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 36 at 38–40Â ; Hepburn v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 386Â ; Waterhouse v Hickie (1995) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-347; BC9504626; John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Blake (2001) 53 NSWLR 541; [2001] NSWCA 434; BC200107417Â . The defence necessarily requires a defendant to identify “another” contextual imputation that differs in character from, and is “not merely a different way of formulating … at a higher level of generality”, the allegedly defamatory imputations relied on by the plaintiff: John Fairfax Publications PtyÂ Ltd v Jones [2004] NSWCA 205; BC200403823 at [16]–[19]Â ; Woodham v John Fairfax Publications PtyÂ Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1204; BC200510618 at [47]Â (imputation of corruption not different in substance from an imputation of dishonesty in relation to the same matter). The statutory requirement that the contextual truth defence must relate to “another” imputation renders inapplicable the limitation contained in Polly Peck (Holdings) plc v Trelford [1986] QB 1000; [1986] 2Â All ER 84Â : see Woodham v John Fairfax Publications at [25]–[26]; Jones v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1133; BC200509661 at [49]–[58]Â . The defendant must specifically plead those contextual imputations: Hepburn , above, at 389, 404; McBride v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2000] NSWSC 747; BC200004412 at [51] and [54]–[56]Â ; Blake , above, at NSWLR 545; Tucker v Echo Publications Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 554; BC200303285Â . The degree of specificity required is the same as in the statement of claim: Marsden v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Levine J, No 20223/95, 4 May 1998, unreported, BC9801561). The contextual imputations relied on by the defendant must be conveyed by the same publication. A defendant cannot rely on third party publications to substantiate the defence: Pioneer International Ltd v Knox (1991) 22 NSWLR 266 at 269Â . A defendant may rely on several different contextual imputations, provided they differ in substance — both from each other and from the imputation alleged by the plaintiff: TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Antoniadis (1998) 44 NSWLR 682; BC8902190Â . For factors to be taken into consideration as to whether a publication on a matter of public concern has been published on an occasion of qualified privilege at common law see Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd [2001] 2 AC 127; [1999] 4 All ER 609; [1999] 3 WLR 1010Â .

leg:heading.title: Defence of absolute privilege

p.text: This rule applies:
to a defence of absolute privilege under Division 3 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 or under section 27 of the Defamation Act 2005, and
to the defence of absolute privilege at common law.
A defence to which this rule applies is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the matter complained of was published under absolute privilege.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.35] r 14.35 Defences for publication of public and official documents

leg:heading.title: Defences for publication of public and official documents
Defence under section 25 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: A defence under section 25 of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the matter complained of was:
a document or record specified as a document or record to which that section applies or a copy of such a document or record, or
a fair summary of, or a fair extract from, such a document or record.

leg:heading.title: Defence under section 27 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: A defence under section 27 of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the matter complained of was a notice published in accordance with the direction of a court.

leg:heading.title: Defence under section 28 of Defamation Act 2005

p.text: A defence under section 28 of the Defamation Act 2005 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the matter complained of was contained in:
a public document or a fair copy of a public document, or
a fair summary of, or a fair extract from, a public document.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.36] r 14.36 Defences of fair report of proceedings of public concern

leg:heading.title: Defences of fair report of proceedings of public concern
Defences under Defamation Act 1974

p.text: A defence under section 24 of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that:
the matter complained of was a fair protected report, or
the matter complained of was a later publication by the defendant of:
a protected report or a copy of the protected report, or a fair extract or fair abstract from, or fair summary of, a protected report that was previously published by another person, or

material purporting to be a protected report or a copy of a protected report, or of a fair extract or fair abstract from, or fair summary of, material purporting to be a protected report that was previously published by another person,

and the defendant did not have knowledge that should have made the defendant aware that the protected report is not fair or the material purporting to be a protected report was not a protected report or is not fair.

leg:heading.title: Defences under Defamation Act 2005

p.text: A defence under section 29 of the Defamation Act 2005 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that:
the matter complained of was, or was contained in, a fair report of any proceedings of public concern, or
the matter complained of:
was, or was contained in, an earlier published report of proceedings of public concern, and
was, or was contained in, a fair copy of, a fair summary of, or a fair extract from, the earlier published report,
and the defendant had no knowledge that would reasonably make the defendant aware that the earlier published report was not fair.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.37] r 14.37 Defence of qualified privilege (cf SCR Part 67, rule 16; DCR Part 49, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Defence of qualified privilege (cf SCR Part 67, rule 16; DCR Part 49, rule 15)

p.text: This rule applies:
to a defence under Division 4 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 or section 30 of the Defamation Act 2005, and
to any other defence of qualified privilege other than any of the following:
a defence under Division 5 , 6 or 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974,
a defence under section 28 , 29 or 31 of the Defamation Act 2005,
the defence of fair comment at common law.
A defence to which this rule applies is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the matter complained of was published under qualified privilege.

The requirement statutory defence of qualified privilege depends on whether the conduct of the defendant in publishing the matter complained of was “reasonable in the circumstances”: s 22(1)(c) Defamation Act 1974; s 30(1)(c) Defamation Act 2005. For a discussion as to what is “reasonable” and a consideration of the matters which a defendant must prove in reliance upon that section see Morgan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (No 2) (1991) 23 NSWLR 374Â . The requirement of reasonableness has been interpreted as reversing the previous common law onus of proof (as to which see Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd [2001] 2 AC 127; [1999] 4 All ER 609; [1999] 3 WLR 1010 at 1027Â ). A defendant relying on the defence of qualified privilege must establish their belief in the truth of what was published and disclose the nature and the source of the information they possessed: Wright v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1977] 1 NSWLR 697 at 705Â ; Morosi v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 749 at 792, 799Â ; Kaiser v George Laurens (NSW) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 294Â . Defamatory imputations, including an unfair report, published in trade and professional journals sent to paying subscribers related to that trade or profession attract the defence of qualified privilege: Bashford v Information Australia (Newsletters) Pty Ltd (2004) 218 CLR 366; 204 ALR 193; 78 ALJR 346 at 354; [2004] HCA 5; BC200400235Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.38] r 14.38 Defences of comment or honest opinion (cf SCR Part 67, rule 17(1) and (2); DCR Part 49, rule 16(1) and (2))

leg:heading.title: Defences of comment or honest opinion (cf SCR Part 67, rule 17(1) and (2); DCR Part 49, rule 16(1) and (2))
Defences under Defamation Act 1974

p.text: A defence under Division 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 is sufficiently pleaded if, as to the matter it alleges was comment, it:
either:
alleges that the comment was comment based on proper material for comment and on no other material, or

alleges that the comment was comment based to some extent on proper material for comment and represented an opinion that might reasonably be based on that material to the extent to which it was proper material for comment, and
alleges that the comment related to a matter of public interest, and
either:
alleges that the comment was the comment of the defendant, or
alleges that the comment was the comment of a servant or agent of the defendant, or

alleges that the comment was not, and in its context and in the circumstances of the publication complained of did not purport to be, the comment of the defendant or of any servant or agent of the defendant.
A defence of fair comment under Division 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 applies to the exclusion of the common law defence of fair comment. See section 29 of the Defamation Act 1974.

leg:heading.title: Defences under Defamation Act 2005

p.text: A defence under section 31 of the Defamation Act 2005 is sufficiently pleaded if, as to the matter it alleges was opinion, it:
either:
alleges that the opinion was based on proper material and on no other material, or

alleges that the opinion was an opinion based to some extent on proper material and represented an opinion that might reasonably be based on that material to the extent to which it was proper material, and
alleges that the opinion was an opinion related to a matter of public interest, and
either:
alleges that the opinion was an expression of opinion of the defendant, or
alleges that the opinion was an expression of opinion of an employee or agent of the defendant, or
alleges that the opinion was an expression of opinion of a person other than the defendant or an employee or agent of the defendant.

A defence of honest opinion under section 31 of the Defamation Act 2005 is in addition to, and does not vitiate, limit or abrogate, the common law defence of fair comment. See section 24(1) of the Defamation Act 2005.

leg:heading.title: Defence of fair comment at common law

p.text: A defence of fair comment at common law is sufficiently pleaded if, as to the matter it alleges was comment, it:
alleges that the comment was comment based on true facts or material that was published under privilege, and
alleges that the comment related to a matter of public interest.
[repealed]
See the note to subrule (2) .
[subr (3) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[4], 1[5], effective 9 June 2006]

The defence of comment in defamation proceedings is directed to the imputations which are established on the pleadings and not to the published matter which gave rise to the imputations: New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council v Perkins (1998) 45 NSWLR 340Â . A general discussion of the statutory defence of comment under the Defamation Act 1974 is contained in Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 474Â ; NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan (NSWSC, Hunt J, 6 February 1981, unreported) at p 9 and Cawley v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 225 at 235–6Â . See also Bob Kay Real Estate Pty Ltd v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 505Â and Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd v Parker (1992) 29 NSWLR 448; (1992) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-200Â .
For a detailed discussion of the particulars required by this rule see Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317Â .

leg:heading.title: Defence of innocent dissemination

p.text: A defence under section 32 of the Defamation Act 2005 is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that:
the defendant published the matter complained of merely in the capacity, or as an employee or agent, of a subordinate distributor, and
the defendant neither knew, nor ought reasonably to have known, that the matter was defamatory, and
the defendant’s lack of knowledge was not due to any negligence on the part of the defendant.

leg:heading.title: Defence of triviality

p.text: This rule applies to:
a defence under section 13 of the Defamation Act 1974, and
a defence under section 33 of the Defamation Act 2005.

A defence to which this rule applies is sufficiently pleaded if it alleges that the circumstances of publication of the matter complained of were such that the plaintiff was unlikely to sustain any harm.
